title: About Me
text:
I am a Vermonter through and through. I grew up in Northern Vermont and got my Bachelors of Science in Mathematics at the Saint Michael’s College. After graduating, I immediately started my graduate studies at the University of Vermont in the Mathematical Science Ph.D. program and within the Vermont Complex Systems Center.
When I am not at my laptop or reading papers, you can find me either in the mountains, where I am hiking, skiing, or ski patrolling, or at a Crossfit class.

title: Mariah C. Boudreau
text: I am a Postdoctoral Researcher with the Network Science Institute at the Roux Institute at Northeastern University. I received a Mathematical Sciences Ph.D. from the Vermont Complex Systems Center at the University of Vermont (UVM). While at UVM, I worked in the Joint Lab and Computational Story Lab. My research has mostly focused on network science applied to infectious diesase. This led me in the direction of mathematical methods for networks, specifically stochastic models that involve branching processes.

title: Mariah C. Boudreau
text:
Recent News

February 2025: Presented Modeling disease spread with probability generating functions at the WiNS online seminar.
September 2024: Started as a Postdoctoral Researcher with the Modeling of Biological and Socio-technical Systems Lab and the Network Science Institute at the Roux Institute at Northeastern University in Portland, ME.
July 2024: Successfully defended my dissertation, Probabilistic modeling of disease: Addressing uncertainties in within-host and population-level dynamics.
June 2024: Attended and presented work from the joint work, Temporal and probabilistic comparisons of epidemic interventions, at NetSci 2024 in Québec City.
October 2023: Completed my comprehensive exam, making me a Ph.D. Candidate in Mathematical Sciences!
October 2023: Joint work with Andrea J. Allen, Nicholas J. Roberts, Antoine Allard, and Laurent Hébert-Dufresne, Temporal and probabilistic comparisons of epidemic interventions is now available on Bulletin of Mathematical Biology!
September 2023: Attended the Grace Hopper Celebration for Women in Tech in Orlando, Florida to explore career opportunities and attend invited talks.
August 2023: Presented a contributed talk titled Sensitivity analysis of stochastic polynomials, and its application to epidemic forecasting and random graphs at Contagion on Complex Social Systems Workshop 2023 at the University of Vermont.
May 2023: Presented on the preprint titled Temporal and probabilistic forecasts of epidemic interventions at the Women in Network Science Minisymposium at SIAM Dynamical Systems 2023 Conference in Portland, Oregon.
May 2023: Attended the Women in Network Science Collabathon at the Network Science Institute at Northeastern University.
April 2023: Presented a poster titled Temporal and probabilistic forecasts of epidemic interventions at the UVM Student Research Conference 2023.
April 2023: Discussed how we can understand the world as networks on the Math 4 All podcast.
February 2023: Joint work with Andrea J. Allen, Nicholas J. Roberts, Antoine Allard, and Laurent Hébert-Dufresne, Temporal and probabilistic forecasts of epidemic interventions is now available on ArXiv!
February 2023: Joint work with Robyn M. Stuart, Jamie A. Cohen, Cliff C. Kerr, Romesh G. Abeysuriya, Marita Zimmerman, Darcy W. Rao, and Daniel J. Klein, HPVsim: An agent-based model of HPV transmission and cervical disease from my contract work with the Gates Foundation is now available on medRXiv!
May 2022: Started my internship/contract work at the Institute for Disease Modeling at the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
